document.masterDocTitle: Neotropical jumping plant-lice (Hemiptera, Psylloidea) associated with plants of the tribe Detarieae (Leguminosae, Detarioideae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Neotropical jumping plant-lice (Hemiptera, Psylloidea) associated with plants of the tribe Detarieae (Leguminosae, Detarioideae)

heading.emphasis:
Key to
Platycorypha
species associated with Detarieae

paragraph.keyLead:
1 Toruli, in ventral view, with dark margin ( Fig. 176 ). Terminalia as in Figs 191 ,
212–214....................
P
. pycnopeus
- Toruli, in ventral view, with light margin. Terminalia different ( Figs 186–190, 192, 193 , 197–211, 215–220 )............. 2

2 Antenna length/ head width ratio <3.8. Paramere lamellar, slender ( Fig. 203 ). Distal portion of aedeagus as in Fig. 205 . Female subgenital plate truncate apically ( Fig. 188 ).........................................................
P. cultrata

5 Apical rostral segment> 1.5 times as long as segment 2. Terminalia as in Figs 187 ,
200–202.................
P
. atrifrons

6 Paramere relatively narrow, with inwards directed apical tooth; inner face with sparse setae ( Figs 218, 219 ). Distal portion of aedeagus as in
Fig. 220.........................................................................
P
. scalprata

- Paramere narrowing from broad base to slender apex with backwards directed apical tooth; inner face with dense setae ( Figs 197, 198, 206, 207 ). Distal portion of aedeagus as in Figs 199, 208.............................................. 7

subSubSection.paragraph:
(Immatures of
Platycorypha atrifrons
,
P. cultrata
,
P. leptopeus
and
P. pycnopeus
are unknown)

paragraph.keyLead:
2 Rostrum long,> 0.7 times forewing pad length, ending distal to metacoxa.................................
P. rostrata

- Rostrum shorter, <0.7 times forewing pad length, ending proximal to metacoxa...........................
P. scalprata

3 Dorsum of caudal plate without submedian capitate setae near submedian sectasetae ( Fig. 194 ).............
P. amazonica

- Dorsum of caudal plate with two short submedian capitate setae near submedian sectasetae ( Fig. 195 )...........
P. pinnata
